Captain Jack Sparrow.Action: Mentions always keeping one man alive for storytelling
Attempts to engage the crowd with humor and charm by politely asking for their attention and help to rob a bank.
Stands defiantly on the roof with a pistol and rum, showing disregard for others' safety and provoking the Royal Guard.
Fires a single shot into the air to startle the guards and signal horses to pull the vault, demonstrating a bold and tactical move.
Attempts to take the vault by having horses pull it, but the vault gets stuck between the iron doors, showing a miscalculation or oversight.
Leads a daring heist by orchestrating the theft of the bank vault in an elaborate, high-risk maneuver.
Jokes lightly about the crew’s hardships and teases them, deflecting concerns with humor rather than addressing their needs.
Acknowledges the crew’s complaints but responds sarcastically, pocketing the single gold coin instead of sharing it.
Attempts to maintain authority by reminding the crew that without him they would be worse off, showing a self-centered perspective rather than empathy.
Promises treasure to his crew, boosting their morale and including even those without pockets humorously.
Uses humor to engage his men and maintain their enthusiasm.
Dismisses Gibbs' suggestion to give up command with confidence and determination.
Jokes about dancing naked in Dove’s Cove, showing a lighthearted personality but little sincerity in addressing serious matters.
Motivates the men by revealing the promise of treasure, using humor and confident declarations to inspire them.
Refuses to give up command despite the crew's doubts and Gibbs' suggestion to step down, showing resilience and leadership.
Confesses to spending years on failed attempts to free the Black Pearl, including seemingly irrational actions like dancing naked, indicating persistence but some questionable decision-making.
Plans to seek help from a witch known to be dangerous, showing willingness to take risks but also potential desperation.
Reassures Scrum by telling him there's nothing to be afraid of except the two-headed dog.
Tells Scrum to go first at the red door despite both being clearly nervous.
Offers gold to Melia as a gesture of goodwill, attempts to negotiate.
Responds with humor to Melia's threat and ominous atmosphere.
Confidently enters a mysterious and potentially dangerous place despite warnings, showing courage and self-assurance.
Offers a gold coin as a bargaining tool when confronting a magical and threatening figure, demonstrating quick thinking and resourcefulness.
Maintains composure and a dry wit even when the enemy performs threatening magic, indicating mental resilience and social skill under pressure.
Expresses casual dismissal of the threat posed by Captain Brand, showing a flippant attitude toward a dangerous enemy.
Shows concern when realizing the seriousness of the situation after Melia's warning.
Quickly rushes to leave upon hearing dangerous information, showing awareness and decisiveness.
Shows concern and realization about the danger posed by Captain Brand and the Devil’s Triangle, demonstrating situational awareness.
Appears initially dismissive or uncertain about the significance of the Trident and the Map No Man Can Read, indicating some hesitation or lack of full understanding.
Underestimates the threat by casually stating Brand will 'have to wait a bit longer,' potentially signaling overconfidence or denial of risk.
Casually tosses his sword into the ocean to avoid threat.
Questions the supposed destiny and chooses to focus on opportunity instead.
Draws his sword and casually tosses it into the ocean immediately after being threatened with it.
Attempts to downplay danger by joking about his dropped sword and calls a swordfish joke, easing tension with humor.
Offers Pig Kelly a gold coin as compensation for borrowing his ship, showing some sense of responsibility or goodwill.
Mocks Pig Kelly's ship by pointing out its flaws despite owing him, showing a lack of tact or sincere respect.
Tries to humorously deny that his sword fell out and is relatively unbothered by the mishap, attempts to move on quickly by opening a barrel of rum and leaving the pub to try another one.
Acknowledges Pig Kelly directly and attempts to offer a gold coin as compensation, showing some social tact and attempt at negotiation despite the threatening situation.
Walks straight into a gun pointed at his head, suggesting a lack of situational awareness or carelessness in a dangerous environment.
Offers to officiate the forced marriage ceremony with dark humor to delay harm.
Uses sarcasm and wit to deal with threat rather than showing aggression or cruelty.
Does not show empathy or kindness to Beatrice despite her hostile behavior and the coercive situation.
Negotiates calmly with Pig Kelly under threat of death, attempts to buy time and manipulate situation with humor and wit.
Responds cleverly to a forced marriage demand with sarcasm and wit, showing quick thinking under pressure.
Does not try to physically resist arrest or escalate conflict when British soldiers burst in, instead surveys situation carefully.
Appears resigned or thoughtful when confronted with fulfillment of the witch’s prophecy, possibly indicating internal acceptance or planning next step.
Uses humor and wit while being beaten and threatened, tries to deflect hostility with lighthearted remarks.
Mocks authority and refuses to engage sincerely with Admiral Scarfield's accusations.

Attempts to talk his way out of a beating by proposing to marry Admiral Scarfield's daughter and distracting him with references to other pirates, displaying quick wit and verbal agility under pressure.
Does not resist physically and passively accepts being beaten by soldiers, showing limited immediate physical capability or assertiveness in this situation.
Shows confidence and a calm demeanor in the face of imminent execution, even joking about the guillotine and the French, indicating mental resilience and presence of mind.
Casually greets his father in prison with a friendly tone.
Engages in a somewhat casual conversation about serious matters with his father showing openness and a familial bond.
Yells back to his father during arrest asking how he chose to die, showing concern and personal connection despite dire circumstances.
Casually greets his father in prison, showing calmness and presence of mind despite being arrested.
Engages in a brief but revealing conversation about dangerous mystical artifacts, showing awareness of important plot elements.
Mentions the Trident and the Eye of Poseidon, demonstrating knowledge of significant mythical items related to his quest.
Does not resist when the British grab him, but rather yells a question back to his father, indicating tactical patience.
Despite being thrown into a jail cell surrounded by cutthroats, maintains composure and awareness.

His crew debates his trustworthiness and actions; Gibbs defends Jack by highlighting his cleverness and hints at a hidden treasure, showing that despite doubts, there is loyalty and belief in Jack’s intentions.
Has not invited his crew to his wedding and is suspected of killing 46 men, causing mistrust and feelings of betrayal among his men.
Gibbs vouches for Jack's cleverness and implies Jack is manipulating lies that eventually lead to truth, indicating Jack's cunning and resourcefulness.
Crew expresses distrust and believes Jack has fleeced them and lied repeatedly, showing a perception of Jack being untrustworthy and possibly incompetent in maintaining loyalty.
Jack is imprisoned and apparently inactive, with no immediate plan shown to escape or act to improve his situation.
Recognizes the significance of Carina Smyth's map and acknowledges his reliance on her to achieve his goal.
Shows apprehension and disgust when witnessing the guillotine execution, demonstrating awareness of consequences.
Attempts to negotiate or delay his execution by requesting to speak to someone and suggesting alternative methods of execution, showing creativity and quick thinking under pressure.
Fails to maintain composure, makes sarcastic remarks to soldiers who are about to execute him, potentially escalating the danger.
Interrupts Carina Smyth's last words with humor despite impending execution, trying to ease tension.
Insults the crowd and Carina by calling them dim-witted and mind of a goat.
Jokes about his impending death and hunger, showing lightheartedness in a dire situation.
Attempts to delay his execution by engaging Carina and the crowd in a distracting, witty dialogue, showing presence of mind under extreme stress.
Mocks Carina’s speech and calls the crowd 'common dim-wittedness and feeble brains,' risking escalating tension in a dangerous situation.
Mocks execution by saying 'Might starve to death first' in the face of death.
Stands ready for execution calmly, closing his eyes before the blade falls.
Commands his crew to fire the cannon to save Carina despite limited resources.
Fights soldiers around him while still restrained in the guillotine locks, showing determination to protect others.
Fires the cannon to save Carina and instructs Gibbs to collect her, showing concern for her wellbeing.
Uses a prisoner's head as a cannonball, showing ruthlessness and lack of mercy.
Confronts Pig Kelly calmly despite threat at his head, showing composure but not overt friendliness.
Uses a prisoner’s head as a cannonball to break the gallows rope and rescue Carina, showing quick improvisation and decisive action.
Commands his crew efficiently to retreat after the bold rescue, maintaining leadership and situational awareness.
Responds calmly and confidently when confronted at gunpoint by Pig Kelly, demonstrating control under pressure.
Manages the standoff by clever use of Beatrice's intervention, turning the threat to his advantage without violence.
Thanks Beatrice with a friendly 'Thank you, darling' before departing.
Refuses to accept the crew's superstition and defends Carina's place on board.
Expresses happiness and a positive attitude about being at sea again.
Shows excitement and pride upon receiving his sword back.
Displays fear and hesitation when reaching for his sword despite excitement.
Tosses the sword into the sea instead of grabbing and using it despite danger.
Throws water on Carina, provoking her and causing distress among the crew.
Claims to have saved Carina's neck, implying a protective action.
Steps in front of Carina to protect her from the accusing crew.
Threatens Carina with a sword at her throat to coerce the map from her.
Dismisses crew’s fear of Carina and tries to convince them she’s not a witch.
Mocks and intimidates the crew by yelling at Gibbs and confusing them.
Recognizes the confusion about the map and tries to simplify the situation for the crew by intervening and protecting Carina.
Uses intimidation (puts sword at Carina's throat) to coerce her into giving up the map.
Fails to maintain pressure or leverage after Carina refuses to cooperate, immediately lowers the sword without securing the map.
Tries to dissuade superstitious crew members from fearing Carina by denying she is a witch, showing awareness of crew morale.
Does not effectively manage the crew’s fear and superstition, allowing tension to rise that undermines his authority.
Offers Carina tea and invites her to join him.
Spikes Carina's tea with rum behind her back.
Engages in witty and friendly conversation about the map and stars, sharing a toast.
Spikes Carina Smyth's tea with rum to gain advantage.
Contributes witty, confident banter indicating knowledge of the map and the Trident.
Demonstrates understanding of celestial navigation concepts through dialogue with Carina.
Shows no signs of hesitation or ignorance when discussing complex clues about the Map and Trident.
Replies to Carina Smyth’s excitement about her destiny with a dismissive 'I hate destiny.'
Says 'You're not the only witch in town' in response to Carina Smyth’s knowledge about the Trident, suggesting cleverness and awareness beyond the obvious.
Says 'I hate destiny' after Carina passes out, indicating possible skepticism or avoidance of fate, showing self-awareness though possibly reluctance to engage decisively.
Waits in a devilish fog in the Devil’s Triangle and springs a trap that destroys Captain Brand’s ship.
Walking Carina around and trying to wake her up when she is passed out on deck, showing concern for her well-being.
Organizes the crew's efforts to wake Carina and shows awareness of the time (setting sun) and its significance for finding a map.
Responds quickly to the threat of an incoming ship, recognizes it as a surprise attack.
Appears resigned and somewhat humorous about his predicament ('Pig Kelly has come to collect his debt. Which is my neck.'), showing an ability to maintain composure under pressure.
Relies on Carina’s expertise for interpreting the stars and navigation instead of taking full control himself.
No direct strategic plan or countermeasure shown to respond to the surprise attack in this excerpt.
Refuses to surrender despite being outgunned, showing resolve and consideration for his crew's morale.
Uses clever tactics such as lighting gunpowder barrels to create a smoke screen, protecting his crew from enemy fire.
Waves to Pig Kelly after ramming his ship, saying 'Surprise.'
Draws his sword but hesitates, unsure which side it is on, then runs away as enemy charges.
Lights barrels of gunpowder and strategically tosses them off the ship to create a curtain of smoke for cover.
Lowers sails and drops anchor just beyond the smoke to set a trap and surprises enemy ship by waiting for them on the other side.
Waves calmly at Pig Kelly after ramming the enemy ship, showing confidence and control of the situation.
When confronted by Kelly on deck, draws his sword but hesitates as he is unsure which side the sword belongs to, then chooses to run.
Uses cleverness and doesn't harm Kelly directly; escapes instead of killing when cornered.
Fights fiercely with his crew during battle.
Run from Kelly when cornered instead of fighting directly, displaying quick thinking to avoid certain death.
Draw sword but immediately question which side it is on, showing momentary confusion.
Acknowledges Carina’s right to name the island and accepts her leadership decisions without argument.
Attempts to speak to Carina in private, indicating a desire for a personal, respectful conversation.
Shows annoyance and sarcasm during the boat conversation, blaming Carina for losing command of ships.
Admits to having kidnapped Carina but defends it by claiming he saved her, showing a complex but protective attitude.
Engages in playful banter with Carina about being a witch and not being a captain, showing tolerance and camaraderie.
Leads men in battle and successfully drives away enemies, resulting in victory and cheers from his crew.
Is cornered by an enemy (Pig Kelly) with a gun pointed at him, appearing vulnerable until an accidental intervention rescues him.
Gets annoyed and admits to losing command of two ships due to mutiny, partially blaming Carina for it.
Acknowledges the complexity of his situation with a self-aware, ironic statement 'And I am not a Captain!'
Engages in playful banter with Carina, showing a lighthearted and humorous side.
Responds to Carina's pride with teasing rather than harsh criticism.
Acknowledges Carina's skills without dismissiveness.
Makes a joke about Venus being 'vertically reclined' which could be seen as slightly mocking.
Confidently states he can find land with his compass and claims it points to exactly where he wishes to go.
Compass points to Carina instead of the intended direction; acknowledges the failure and says 'Broken. Let’s try it your way.'
Escape from Port Royal and evade Barbossa's pursuit by favoring specific sailing lines, demonstrating knowledge and cunning.
Crew mutinies against him leading to him being set adrift with a witch.
Secretly happy that Carina is lost despite her suffering, drinks the last of the rum without sharing.
Makes a teasing, sarcastic comment to Carina calling her praise 'high praise coming from a horologist.'
Slides very close to Carina without evident concern for her discomfort when offering help with the map.
Shows some interest in Carina’s personal story when asking about her earring and her father.
Engages in thoughtful banter with Carina, showing playful tolerance and gentle teasing.
Describes the port as 'a very friendly place' sarcastically despite its vicious inhabitants.
Sniffs the air to detect land and successfully identifies an island in the distance.
Makes a witty remark about being lost and skeptical about star navigation.
Appears confident in navigating by the horizon rather than celestial navigation.
Calls Coronation Bay a very friendly place, encouraging Carina.
Acknowledges the need for a feminine gull to ask for assistance, indicating support for Carina's role.
Pulls Carina in and kisses her, claiming it is for luck.
Steals Carina’s map by pickpocketing during the kiss and runs away.
Sees Carina Smyth being dragged off but initially avoids intervening and instead has a drink.
Acknowledges Carina is the only one who can read the map, implying some trust or reliance on her.
Knocks out two gamblers casually and takes his sword, preparing to act.
Attempts to bid to save Carina despite having empty pockets, showing care and willingness to help her in a dire situation.
Mocks Carina by calling her of unremarkable stock and lacking warmth, a dismissive and sarcastic comment.
Steals money from a dishonest bidder during an auction to prevent the man from swindling a reputable woman.
Steals money skillfully from the bidder's pockets while bidding in the auction, using distraction and sleight of hand to outsmart the opponent and win the bid without paying.
Follows the pirate and Carina to the ship and stealthily rescues Carina by climbing aboard and freeing her.
Quickly climbs the side of the ship, uses two pirates to pull himself aboard stealthily.
Sneaks along the deck and climbs into the captain's quarters through a window without being detected.
Enters the captain's quarters to rescue Carina despite the obvious danger, demonstrating courage and initiative.
Is immediately surrounded and seemingly outnumbered by Barbossa’s men, potentially indicating a lack of situational control.
Designates Scrum as captain in case something happens to him, showing foresight and leadership.
His crew is depicted as depressed, unsure what to do, suggesting that his absence leaves a leadership void.
Requests help from Henry Maddox despite being chained and vulnerable.
Gives Henry advice about rescuing women, though cynically suggesting kidnapping and ransom instead.
Keeps calm and composed despite being tied up in chains and in a dangerous situation, showing awareness of his environment (e.g., noticing the noise and reacting quickly).
Engages Henry Maddox by speaking clearly and confidently, attempting to recruit help despite being restrained.
Makes a witty, somewhat cynical comment about rescuing women, showing quick thinking and street-smart advice.
Suggests an unconventional plan to squeal like a parrot to gain help, indicating quick thinking and confidence in a dire situation.
Looks for a key to escape from chains, demonstrating practical problem-solving and situational awareness.
Relies on others to free him rather than escaping on his own, which could indicate dependence or lack of immediate resourcefulness.
Uses his broken chains to disable enemies, shares weapons with Henry Maddox, encourages him to fight alongside him.
Uses broken chains as a weapon to incapacitate an opponent and skillfully takes swords from enemies.
Recognizes Henry Maddox's inexperience but effectively trains and arms him by giving him a weapon better suited to his skill (hammer).
Confidently leads Henry Maddox in taking the ship despite being outnumbered.
Places a sword at Barbossa's back to take control of the ship, initiating a tense confrontation.
Places a sword to Barbossa's back to assert control and attempts to take the Pearl in a tense, dangerous moment.
Uses calm verbal banter under pressure, suggesting confidence and control in a precarious situation.
Initiates a confrontation with Barbossa despite the dangerous conditions and stakes involved.
Obeys Barbossa's order to take the wheel and focuses on maneuvering the ship to prioritize survival over fighting.
Takes the wheel of the ship during a critical cannon attack and maneuvers the ship quickly despite the cannon fire and fighting the current.
Fights side by side with Barbossa against common enemies.
Stays at the wheel of the ship during battle, maintaining focus and leadership.
Going to the wheel and turning the ship as fast as he can, fighting the current during a chaotic battle.
Stays at the wheel of the Revenge calmly as the ghost ship Silent Mary approaches, showing presence of mind amid supernatural threat.
Making a dry comment 'Can't be good...' in a tense, uncertain situation, indicating awareness but not necessarily a proactive or confident approach.
Tip-toes behind the mast trying to hide while others face the impending battle.
Tip-toes behind the mast trying to hide as the battle and boarding approach.
Hides behind the mast, terrified when confronted by Captain Brand instead of standing up openly.
Stays hidden behind the mast, peeks out cautiously to spy on Captain Brand rather than confronting him directly.
Appears terrified and backs up as Brand approaches him with a sword, showing fear and reluctance to face danger.
Saves Eric’s life despite putting Captain Brand at risk.
Responds with sarcastic humor when Carina calls herself a witch or wench.
Dismisses Captain Brand's claim of love with a flippant remark.
Steers the ship with his hands behind him, moving it halfway out of the Triangle to save himself from immediate danger.
Loses control as the ship drifts back over the line, forcing him into a desperate struggle and ultimately being overpowered and thrown across the ship.
Throws Carina into the water to save her from ghost attackers.
Remembers the bottle and goes back for it instead of immediately escaping.
Reaches into Brand’s coat and pulls out the diamond to negotiate or survive.
Throws Carina into the water to save her from the ghosts.
Remembers the bottle and goes back for it before jumping into the water.
While being held over the side by Brand, reaches into Brand's coat, pulls out the diamond, and uses it to negotiate or distract.
Holds Henry Maddox back from going back into the dangerous water to save Olivia, preventing him from certain death.
Responds to Carina's fear with light humor about not seeing a lizard or a Quaker.
Encourages Carina to lead the way to the Trident of Poseidon.
Jokes to lighten tense atmosphere (mentions not seeing a lizard or a Quaker).
Correctly identifies location as the Coffin Islands based on local knowledge.
Tells Carina 'Then lead the way' confidently, showing trust in others' competence.
Does not attempt to take command or assert authority while others organize, showing situational awareness.
Keeps the diamond secretly despite others' demands.
Responds with feigned confusion to avoid confrontation.
Successfully conceals the diamond in his pocket and later reveals it only when confronted, showing calculated behavior.
Remains calm and confident under threat when Barbossa holds a dagger to his throat, indicating composure and presence of mind.
No indication of panic or rashness in dangerous situations (such as the plant attacks), implying measured and skilled responses.
Acknowledges Barbossa's feelings toward Carina with a teasing but understanding comment about age and marriage.
Initiates physical contact by grabbing Barbossa’s hand to reveal his tattoo, showing engagement and openness.
Probes Barbossa gently about Carina's connection to piracy and the stolen book, signaling curiosity without aggression.
Uses sarcasm or dismissive tone when saying 'I’m confused, Hector' after being accused of stealing the diamond.
Notices the tattoo of a clover on Barbossa's wrist, connects it to Carina's earring and pirate markings in her diary, draws logical conclusions about the stolen book and its significance.
Feigns confusion when confronted about the diamond to deflect suspicion.
Seeks to defuse tension or redirect the conversation by commenting on Barbossa's feelings for Carina and giving advice about marriage.
Engages in negotiation with Barbossa to avoid conflict, agrees to an accord despite mutual distrust.
Mocks Barbossa's appearance with sarcastic remarks.
Willing to respect Barbossa's wish to keep Carina away from the pirate life, showing some respect for Barbossa's paternal concern.
Strikes an accord with Barbossa to gain the Pearl and his life without escalating conflict.
Uses humor to diffuse tension when confronted by Barbossa's insults about his appearance.
Agrees quickly to Barbossa’s terms despite the risk, showing pragmatism and strategic thinking.
Fails to foresee Barbossa pulling a gun immediately after shaking hands, putting himself briefly at lethal risk.
Tries to avoid Carina to keep appearances and avoid suspicion, showing reluctance to engage but not dismissive.
Acknowledges past wrongs to Carina honestly, admitting to kidnapping and mutiny.
Pushes through thick brush and heavy plants to move ahead alone, showing determination and physical capability.
Attempts to avoid Carina to prevent suspicion, showing awareness of danger and strategic thinking.
Engages in wordplay with Carina, maintaining a playful but cautious demeanor despite threats.
Acknowledges mistakes such as kidnapping Carina and causing mutiny, demonstrating self-awareness but also reminding of past poor decisions.
Acknowledges relationship with Carina by admitting 'there is something between us' after her kiss.
Mentions being married with 'two unbearable children' humorously to deflect intimacy.
Shows relief and concern for Carina's safety as she moves through the clearing.
Quickly gives into Carina's kiss without hesitation.
Observes the alignment of the rocks and their pointed direction, showing situational awareness.
Smoothly engages in dialogue, lightly deflecting serious topics with humor.
Cuts off the bird's feet to save Carina from being taken by the massive bird.
Runs away declaring 'This is where I run.' before the bird attacks begin.
Cuts off the bird’s feet to save Carina from being taken by the giant bird.
Tackles Barbossa to save him from the attacking bird.
Uses Barbossa’s wooden leg as a weapon to protect them both from the giant bird.
Rushes with Barbossa and other survivors into the cave and shares moment of awe and wonder at the jeweled cave walls.
Uses Barbossa's wooden leg effectively as a weapon to incapacitate a giant attacking bird.
Quickly recognizes the danger and instructs to run for safety after attacking the bird.
Walks deeper into the cave and observes the jewel-covered walls, showing curiosity and awareness of surroundings.
Calmly acknowledges the presence of the cave’s significance by saying 'We're past that' to dismiss superstitious panic among pirates.
Does not intervene when a pirate rashly tries to take a diamond and falls to his death due to a hidden trap.
Engages in the group’s conversation by asking an earnest question about the stars they are searching for.
Makes a lighthearted comment about birds when faced with the imposing fortress, showing a friendly and approachable demeanor.
Warns the pirates to run as the bottle with the Black Pearl shatters, showing concern for their safety despite their confusion.
Shows a brief moment of self-awareness and mild embarrassment when his small model ship falls on his foot and he comments playfully about size.
Picks up a small model of the Black Pearl and jokes about its size, then accidentally drops the anchor on his foot and looks embarrassed.
Runs determinedly through the maze of the fortress despite ghost soldiers attacking, showing awareness of danger and urgency.
Faces Gibbs and Scrum calmly and prepares to fight his way out, displaying leadership and readiness.
Makes a lighthearted comment about Gibbs and Scrum's ghostly appearance in the face of imminent danger, showing wit and confidence under pressure.
Attempts to not kill Gibbs and Scrum while fighting for his life.
Jokes about doubling and tripling wages despite dangerous situation.
Acknowledges that Gibbs and Scrum are upset with him.
Fights off multiple ghost enemies, manages to cut Scrum's hand while trying to avoid killing his former crewmates, uses sword effectively to defend and escape.
Attempts to negotiate with ghost enemies mid-fight by joking about wages and doubling/tripling them, showing quick wit and presence of mind under pressure.
Shows horror and surprise at being attacked by former allies, indicating a lapse in situational awareness beforehand.
Hears the massive wave approaching and immediately warns Barbossa to take cover, then shields Barbossa from the impact by throwing himself on top of him.
Shows concern for Barbossa's condition and lightly jokes by pretending to slap him, indicating a familiar camaraderie.
Observes the reflection from Carina's chronometer and quietly acknowledges she is alive, showing attention and care for others.
Sees the reflection in the distance and immediately recognizes what it is, demonstrating awareness and quick perception.
Swings in to rescue Carina by handing her a rope to escape the Silent Mary.
Arrives precisely in the nick of time to rescue Carina, swinging across and handing her the rope, demonstrating excellent timing under pressure.
Hands Carina a rope to help her escape despite danger.
Uses being stabbed as a tactic to escape, prioritizing his own survival.
Swings across from the Black Pearl at just the right moment and provides Carina a rope to escape, showing precise timing and situational awareness.
Attempts to grab a rope to escape but it is cut down by a sword, putting him momentarily at a disadvantage.
Allows himself to be stabbed intentionally, using being wounded as part of a strategic ploy.
Immediately recovers from being stabbed and sprints to secure a second rope to escape.
Expresses confidence and swagger even after injury, demonstrating mental resilience and tactical confidence.
Grabs the trident and pulls it out of his shoulder despite pain to continue fighting.
Stares out at the sea with wonder and reverence.
Expresses belief that no one should control the sea.
Pulls the trident out of his shoulder despite the pain, demonstrating resilience and determination.
Looks out at the sea with a familiar look of wonder, reflecting thoughtful awareness but no direct action.
Raises the Trident to reveal the ocean's secrets, showing care for greater good.
Insists on returning the Trident despite having power, accepting personal risk.
Jokes about Carina's concern and his own destiny in a lighthearted manner.
Maintains composure and identifies the location of the golden tomb quickly after crashing to the ocean floor.
Urges Carina to hurry in a dangerous, time-sensitive situation showing situational awareness.
Navigates underwater shipwrecks and terrain skillfully while racing Carina to the golden tomb, demonstrating awareness and agility.
Pauses briefly to admire diamonds on the walls amidst urgent escape, showing a momentary distraction but maintaining focus overall.
Stops momentarily to eye the diamonds on the walls while racing underwater with Carina.
Struggles with Carina to push the heavy lid of Poseidon's tomb aside under dangerous circumstances.
Remains composed and delivers a dry remark when confronted by Captain Brand wielding his sword threateningly.
Raises the trident at the last second to block the sword, successfully cutting the sword and causing the ancient scepter to drop.
Observes the walls of water starting to buckle and notices something in the distance, showing situational awareness.
Notices the anchor dropped from the Black Pearl in the midst of chaotic collapsing waters and acts quickly to save himself and Carina by running, jumping, and holding onto the ship.
Hands Carina 'The Eye' diamond as a sign of trust and encouragement.
Engages in friendly conversation with Carina about her future and beliefs.
Smiles mysteriously and keeps diamonds, indicating playful deception without malice.
Hands all of the diamonds to Scrum as promised, showing follow-through and trust in his crew.
Hesitates for a long beat before taking his sword and putting it in his belt, indicating a moment of uncertainty or delay.
Expresses a clear plan to follow the stars, showing confident navigation and leadership.
Suggests renaming the Black Pearl to Barbossa, indicating strategic thinking to strike fear and gain advantage.
